Posts.Content: Strike_Two wrote: Due to horrible infection, my doc had to remove my TEs several days after BMX and TE placement.   I still HURT. My chest feels very tight, but why?  I understood that I would have the tight feeling with the TEs, but it's still tight. Original surgery was Dec. 3, TEs were removed a few days later, and I had two or three more procedures afterwards to clean out infection.  (Can't remember exact number due to drugs. :)  Then a skin graft on one side. What was your experience? 12/03/12 BMX with TEs. ILC, Stage 2b, grade 1, 1/4 nodes positive. TE's removed due to infection. Multiple procedures to clean out infection. Blood transfusions. Sent home on wound vac. 9/2007 DCIS, grade 2-3, lumpectomy, rads Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: If You Had Your TEs Removed, Please Check in Here Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 06:39AM Strike_Two wrote: Cbear, sorry you are going through this.  Most likely you will be sent on to another doctor after your surgery. Some type of oncologist who will look at your overall picture and help you decide whether you need radiation, hormone therapy, and what not, so at that time definitely go with a doctor you like and trust. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Anyone had 40% k167 score and low oconotype test scores cbear Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2012 06:02PM Strike_Two wrote: Oh, I'm so sorry you are going through this.  I think of my beautiful four month old granddaughter and how much she needs her mommy and how much your baby girl needs you. Try to calm down.  I know that's hard to do - especially on a Friday night when you know you won't here anything for a couple of days.  Just remember that cancer treatments are leaps and bounds ahead of what they were years ago, and the side effects of any treatment are generally more tolerable, as well. Do  you have a partner to talk to?  Or a good friend?  We're here for you. Peace be with you.
Posts.Title: Terrified Mirmirpanda neugirl

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2012 09:32AM - edited Nov 24, 2012 09:33AM by Strike_Two Your post is making me nervous.  Five years ago I had to delay radiation on my right breast because I reacted so horribly to the tape used after my lumpectomy.   "That" was much more painful than any radiation burn I got later.  Seriously,  I blistered and oozed from the tape, not the radiation, and it took forever to heal, whereas I normally heal quickly.  I feel for you.  I hope everything goes well.
Posts.Title: Kineso tape left 2 big red welts, when pulled off hugz4u Musical

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2013 11:51PM Strike_Two wrote: Virginia, thank you for taking the time to reply.   You know, I was so out of it with so much infection and fever that there is a lot I don't remember.  It seems impossible that I would have muscle between my skin and my ribs - there's nothing there!  Could I have lost my entire muscle?  That doesn't seem right, and it's very puzzling.   I was taken back three or four times to the operating room over several days to clean out the infection, but it never dawned on me that I might have lost tissue or muscle in the process! Strike
Posts.Title: Anyone's Skin Stuck to Chest After Wound Vac Treatment? TIGHT! Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Strike_Two wrote: I haven't been around in a while, so brief history -  my surgery was at the beginning of December, my body rejected the the right tissue expander, and I spent three weeks in the hospital being treated for massive infection.  :(  Blood transfusions, massive antibiotics, more surgeries,  home on a wound vac with a nurse because we were trying to get me healed more quickly so I could start chemo.  The infection really delayed my treatment start, but I am now finished and bald.  :)  Treatment was a breeze compared to what I'd been through earlier.   Anyway, the wound vac basically "vaccuum packed" my skin to my chest, and it is NOT moving.  It's awful.  I can't get comfortable at night, especially.   Can someone tell me if this gets any better?  My plastic surgeon seems to think that the only way to "unstick" me is to do reconstruction and stick something under there - most likely tram surgery.  But after the drama of December, I have to say that I'm a bit frightened of more surgery, and I write this as someone who has a lot of experience with surgery and have never really been frightened before.   Does it ever get better?   12/03/12 BMX with TEs. ILC, Stage 2b, grade 1, 1/4 nodes positive. TE's removed due to infection. Multiple procedures to clean out infection. Blood transfusions. Sent home on wound vac. 9/2007 DCIS, grade 2-3, lumpectomy, rads Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone's Skin Stuck to Chest After Wound Vac Treatment? TIGHT! Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2013 12:49PM - edited Jun 20, 2013 12:54PM by Strike_Two Has no one ever had this problem but me? I've been reading about other women who have used wound vacs here, but I haven't found anyone who describes this yet.  Since there's no breast tissue lef or fat, my skin has "stuck" to whatever is left. Is that a muscle?  If it is, it's awfully thin.  I can feel my ribs as if though paper, and  my skin does not move at all.   It's weird.  It's very uncomfortable.  :( Kindest regards to all of you diagnosed with this disease.
Posts.Title: Anyone's Skin Stuck to Chest After Wound Vac Treatment? TIGHT! Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2013 05:18PM Strike_Two wrote: Thanks for the reply.  Yeah, I had a skin graft, as well.  It does NOT move.  I seriously can't imagine therapy helping, since I have been massaging the darn area for months, but I will definitely look into it!  Like you wrote, it's paper think and just looks like the whole area is sucked in.   Flat?    I'd be thrilled to be "flat"  at the moment. LOL

Posts.Title: Ugh. Second Cancer, Different Breast Strike_Two Strike_Two

Posts.Content: Strike_Two wrote: Five years ago upon just turning fifty, I was diagnosed with DCIS in my right breast and chose to have a lumpectomy with rads.   Everything went fine, and I healed beautifully.   Barely noticeable.  This week, I have been diagnosed with Invasive Lobular Cancer in my left breast, grade 1, 1.4 centimeters, ER +, Her2 -.   Stage 1, unless more is found when I have surgery. I didn't get hung up on the DCIS diagnosis, but the lobular cancer is certainly more upsetting to me since it can be "sneaky," as my breast surgeon explains.  :( I am considering a double mastectomy this time, but since I have  had rads on my right breast already, I understand that my reconstructive options are more limited.   Lucky me.  And since this is a second diagnosis of breast cancer, I'm going to do genetic testing, since it now puts me in a high risk category, and I want to know if my daughters are at risk for this.  sigh Any words of wisdom?  Advice?  Anyone else in similar circumstances?  Thanks. 12/03/12 BMX with TEs. ILC, Stage 2b, grade 1, 1/4 nodes positive. TE's removed due to infection. Multiple procedures to clean out infection. Blood transfusions. Sent home on wound vac. 9/2007 DCIS, grade 2-3, lumpectomy, rads Log in to post a reply

What do I do to prepare?  What did you wear in the hospital?  When you came home?   Will I have drains?   I'm a side sleeper 99% of the time, and I've been reading that won't be possible.  ugh  I'm getting kind of down.  sigh 12/03/12 BMX with TEs. ILC, Stage 2b, grade 1, 1/4 nodes positive. TE's removed due to infection. Multiple procedures to clean out infection. Blood transfusions. Posts.Title: Bilateral Mastectomy & TEs Scheduled for December 3rd Strike_Two mdg

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 09:40PM - edited Nov 28, 2012 09:42PM by Strike_Two  I was tested and am awaiting results because I'm now on my second breast cancer, and my first was before the age of fifty.  Granted, I was forty-nine. :) However, my father died of cancer of an unknown primary, and looking back, his cancer spread in a manner that "could" have been consistent with breast cancer.   And it sure does seem like the doctors checked for everything but breast cancer. The results won't affect my decision, since I have already opted for a bilat mast, but I have daughters and nieces to think about.

Posts.Content: Strike_Two wrote: l've been posting, and have already had my BMX, with complications, of course.  :(   (TE's have been removed due to infection.) I was under the care of my breast surgeon (who has been my doc for about 8 years) and my plastic surgeon, and had recommendations for two different oncologists.  I've already ruled out one, so am looking for other recommendations in the Houston area. Do you prefer working with one doctor or having a team of doctors?  If you have a team, does your team include a lymphodema specialist?   Although I think my doctors were excellent, I'm not completely happy with the piecemeal  approach to my care. I have stage 2b, lobular cancer, ER+, HER-, and am currently on an  antibiotic regimen and wound vac.  I hope to leave the hospital Monday morning (with antibiotics and portable wound vac.) Please feel free to private message me if you don't want to share on the open board. Thanks!  Hope you all find some peace and joy this holiday season. 12/03/12 BMX with TEs. ILC, Stage 2b, grade 1, 1/4 nodes positive. TE's removed due to infection. Multiple procedures to clean out infection. Blood transfusions.
